Since the adoption of HE introduces computational and communicational overheads, many works focus on alleviating the efficiency problem. For example,Â (Yang etÂ al., 2021; Wei etÂ al., 2021; Yang etÂ al., 2019c) construct similar VFL secure protocols based on HE for linear models. However, the partial local estimate is disclosed for better efficiency. Â (Liu etÂ al., 2019) conducts multiple local updates before communication to reduce communication rounds to improve efficiency. Also aiming to reduce communication rounds,Â (Yang etÂ al., 2019a) adopted the quasi-Newton method for fast convergence.Â (Li etÂ al., 2020) designed gradient prediction and double-end sparse compression for acceleration. Furthermore,Â (Wei etÂ al., 2021; Yu etÂ al., 2022) utilize CKKS instead of Paillier, a common choice in VFL, to train VFL logistic regression. Their designs result in better efficiency due to the single instruction multiple data (SIMD) property of CKKS.Â (Wei etÂ al., 2021) chooses to encrypt the intermediate results, whileÂ (Yu etÂ al., 2022) encrypts the original data directly. Besides, ACCELÂ (Zhao etÂ al., 2022a) utilized symmetric homomorphic encryption (SHE)Â (Mahdikhani etÂ al., 2020) to implement a data aggregation matrix construction protocol for vertical federated logistic regression to improve training efficiency. Based on ACCEL, VFLRÂ (Zhao etÂ al., 2023) designed a novel vertical federated query scheme for inference.Â (Dai etÂ al., 2022) incorporated distributed computing (DC) into vertical federated linear regression, where each party contains multiple workers. In more detail, the authors utilized coded DCÂ (Lee etÂ al., 2017), which could obtain the expected results with the alive workers, to alleviate the straggler problem.

For the scenarios withÂ S2 security model,Â (Weng etÂ al., 2020) proposed the reverse multiplication attack, which could result in the leakage of private data. Corrupted by adversaries, party A colludes with coordinator C to successfully conduct the attack. However, the attack is affected by the batch size and learning rate. We could set large batch size and small learning for defense.

SS-Based Vertical Federated Linear Algorithm.

The main idea of SS-based algorithms is sharing model weights (or even the original data,Â etc.) over different parties and conducting computations in the form of secret shares. Privacy is further protected because there is no leakage of the intermediate results. An intuitive method is to secretly sharing local original data to other parties, and all parties collaboratively train models on data sharesÂ (Mohassel and Zhang, 2017; Demmler etÂ al., 2015; Mohassel and Rindal, 2018). However, this kind of method suffers from high communication overhead. Therefore, there exist many works which do not directly share original data but intermediate results instead. For example, GascÃ³nÂ et al. combined SS with GC and OT to design a hybrid protocol for vertical linear regression modelsÂ (GascÃ³n etÂ al., 2017). They generate additive shares of intermediate results for linear regression model via a secure inner product protocol and adopt GC to solve the distributed equation. The intermediate results are not revealed to any party. Only the final model weight is shown to parties. However, there exists a strong assumption that two additional parties (i.e., crypto service provider and evaluator introduced by GC) do not collude with each other. Besides, ChenÂ et al. also chose to secretly share model parameters to reduce the high communication overhead caused by high-dimensional sparse dataÂ (Chen etÂ al., 2021a). In detail, they design a secure sparse matrix multiplication protocol combining SS and HE. HuangÂ et al. also proposed an HE and SS hybrid protocol for generalized linear models. They secretly share the intermediate results instead of model weights for better efficiency and party extension. However, SS-based algorithms have slight accuracy loss because of the approximate of non-linear parts. ForÂ S3 security model,Â (Mohassel and Rindal, 2018; Dalskov etÂ al., 2021) provide variants of building blocks that could defend against malicious adversaries.

DP-Based Vertical Federated Linear Algorithm.

Besides the HE- and SS-based protocols, DP-based protocols could further protect the privacy of federated prediction resultsÂ (Xu etÂ al., 2019; Wang etÂ al., 2020a). Many VFL attacks are conducted utilizing model predictions. For example, LuoÂ et al. designed the feature inference attack for vertical linear algorithmsÂ (Luo etÂ al., 2021b). The active party performs the attack and tries to infer the features owned by the passive party. However, the authors strongly assume that the active party knows the model parameters of the passive party, which is difficult to achieve in real-world scenarios. Furthermore, JiangÂ et al. proposed a more effective attack based on the same settingÂ (Jiang etÂ al., 2022), which relieves the assumption from the leakage of passive partyâ€™s model parameters to the prior knowledge of a small set of auxiliary samples. DP could be used to defend against these attacks, but it also results in accuracy loss. DP could be a complementation for HE- and SS-based protocols. Based on the functional mechanism of DP,Â (Xu etÂ al., 2019) divides the objective function into multiple parties and injects noises separately.Â (Wang etÂ al., 2020a) adds noises to the intermediate results.

Vertical Federated Linear Algorithm with Other Protocols.

Besides the above three kinds of protocols, there exist many other methods for better efficiency while maintaining accuracy. For example,Â (Li etÂ al., 2016; Kim etÂ al., 2021) proposed to exchange the plain-text local gram matrix instead of the original data during the vertical federated logistic regression training process, which is claimed to be secure as long as there are enough local covariates. In addition, FDML utilizes an ensemble method to design the secure protocol, where each party conducts partial inference, and all the plaintext predictions are aggregated as the final resultsÂ (Hu etÂ al., 2019). Worthing to note, the scheme of FMDL could also be applied to other VFL algorithms.Â (Zhang etÂ al., 2021c, b; Gu etÂ al., 2021) utilize RM to protect the plain-text intermediate results. The final value could be recovered by removing all masks. Similarly, CaiÂ et al. proposed an efficient vertical federated ridge regression algorithm over large-scale data based on RMÂ (Cai etÂ al., 2022b). They could directly use the masked data for computation and remove the masks to obtain the expected results. Moreover, SunÂ et al. and ShiÂ et al. adopted the MPC-based secure aggregation protocolÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) to improve the efficiency of VFLÂ (Sun etÂ al., 2022a; Shi etÂ al., 2022), which can be easily extended to scenarios with more participants. The authors stated that this framework could also suit other more complicated machine learning models. Besides,Â (Gu etÂ al., 2021) utilizes tree-structured communication schemes for better efficiency. In addition, NathanÂ et al. propose first-order dual optimization methods for large-scale feature distributed optimizationÂ (Nathan and Klabjan, 2017). First-order methods explicitly compute the first-order derivatives and perform iterative optimization. Due to their versatility, first-order methods are extensively studied in VFL.Â (Zhang etÂ al., 2021c) incorporates approximate second-order information to reduce the number of communication rounds.Â (Zhang etÂ al., 2021a) utilizes the zeroth-order optimization to design a novel vertical linear algorithm.

For the scenarios withÂ S2 security model,Â (Zhang etÂ al., 2021c, b, a) claimed their algorithms are secure. Even though the RM could be removed by colluding,Â (Zhang etÂ al., 2021c, b) indicated that exactly revealing the original data and model weights is still impossible.Â (Zhang etÂ al., 2021a) also claimed to be secure even forÂ S2 security model.Â (Cai etÂ al., 2022b) also provided security analysis forÂ S1,Â S2 andÂ S4 assumption. ForÂ O2, the backdoor attack in VFL could harm the utility of federated models via injecting triggers in gradientsÂ (Liu etÂ al., 2020c).Â (Zhang etÂ al., 2021a) proposed only to transmit the function values. Therefore, the corrupted parties could not access the intermediate gradients to conduct such attacks. Besides,Â (Yuan etÂ al., 2022) showed that Byzantine attack exists in VFL and proposed a dual subgradient method for the linear algorithm.

Asynchronization. Although the commonly utilized synchronous optimization method ensures that VFL is lossless, it requires all parties to compute and communicate intermediate results for every iteration, which suffers from two drawbacks: 1) it incurs a high communication cost; 2) synchronization among parties is prone to stragglers. Asynchronous methods are proposed to break the synchronization barrier.Â (Liu etÂ al., 2019; Wei etÂ al., 2021) suggested conducting multiple updates locally at each party before exchanging stale (i.e., several iterations behind) information. However, LiÂ et al. found this simple implementation of the asynchronized mechanism performs poorly in most casesÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020). The reason is that the â€œstale result problemâ€ is much more severe in VFL, whose participants have different computational power, data amount, and network environment. Therefore, this work is further designed to narrow the gap between the received and current intermediate results. FDML also proposed a similar intuitive asynchronized methodÂ (Hu etÂ al., 2019). AndÂ (Gu etÂ al., 2021; Zhang etÂ al., 2021b) extended FDML in two ways. First, they present asynchronous versions of variance reduction methods and theoretically analyze their convergence. Second, they do not require shared labels.Â (Zhang etÂ al., 2022b) found that unbalanced features could further harm the convergence of asynchronous methods. The authors proposed a novel optimization method that adaptively chooses the number of local updates for each party.

Vertical Federated Tree Algorithm

Tree models are also widely used to model tabular data. A single decision tree consists of a series of decision rules, where each sample is classified by traversing from the root and following the decision rules to the leaf nodes. In practice, it is common to build ensembles of trees, including gradient boosting decision trees (GBDT)Â (Ke etÂ al., 2017), random forests (RF)Â (Ho, 1995), and XgBoostÂ (Chen and Guestrin, 2016). Vertical federated tree algorithm is among researchersâ€™ most popular VFL algorithms because of its effectiveness. We show the categorization of current vertical federated tree algorithms in Tab.Â 3.

HE-Based Vertical Federated Tree Algorithm.

(Cheng etÂ al., 2021a; Feng etÂ al., 2019) proposed vertical federated GBDT algorithms based on HE, withÂ (Cheng etÂ al., 2021a) discussing potential information leakage. They utilize HE to encrypt the statistical values transferred from active party to passive parties. Then, the active parties could perform addition operations on the encrypted values and send them back to the active party. Besides, SecureBoostÂ (Cheng etÂ al., 2021a) also tries to train the first tree locally in active party and treats its prediction as the mask to reduce information leakage, a similar idea to RM. Based on SecureBoost,Â (Zhang etÂ al., 2022c) designed a vertical federated feature selection algorithm with an evolutionary optimization technique called particle swarm optimizationÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2020c).Â (Zhu etÂ al., 2021a) studied a different setting where labels are also distributed across parties, and they leveraged HE and DP to protect the distributed features and labels. Moreover, MaoÂ et al. applied the HE-based vertical federated tree model to the area of power gridÂ (Mao etÂ al., 2023), showing the algorithmâ€™s effectiveness. To achieve a secure query,Â (Zhao etÂ al., 2022b) proposed an oblivious query algorithm based onÂ (Mahdikhani etÂ al., 2020). Users could utilize the well-trained vertical federated tree model without leaking their queries and results. Besides,Â (Xia etÂ al., 2022) further adopted autoencoder to transform the high-dimension sparse original features into lowâ€dimension dense representation, which is more suitable for tree models. These HE-based methods generally incur large computation overhead. Thus, several works aim to improve the efficiency of tree ensembles in VFL. VF2Boost improves vertical federated GBDT in two ways: concurrent training to reduce idle waiting and customizing encryption for trainingÂ (Fu etÂ al., 2021). In more detail, it VF2Boost re-scheduling method to sort the encrypted values to be accumulated according to the exponential terms to reduce the number of scaling operations and thus improve efficiency. Besides, VF-CART reduces communication costs by converting feature values to bin values and building histogramsÂ (Xu etÂ al., 2023).

Furthermore, several works combine HE with SS to protect the intermediate computational results from leaking to any party (including the local party). For instance, Pivot combines SS and HE to guarantee that no intermediate information is disclosed when building general tree models, including RF and GBDTÂ (Wu etÂ al., 2020). Considering the high communication complexity of SS, SS is only utilized in the operations,Â e.g., comparison, which HE does not support. Each party conducts most of the local computations with HE. Besides, the prediction path can be protected via an HE-based protocol to prevent information leakage along the path. CryptoBoost utilized the multi-party homomorphic encryption (MHE) techniqueÂ (Mouchet etÂ al., 2021) to design an end-to-end secure vertical federated XgBoostÂ (Jin etÂ al., 2022). MHE takes advantage of SS to reduce the considerable computational cost introduced by HE.

SS-Based Vertical Federated Tree Algorithm

There are fewer vertical federated tree algorithms designed mainly using SS techniques. The reason could be that utilizing SS to implement complicated algorithms needs large design efforts. Naive designs will result in severe communicational overheads. One of the SS-based vertical federated tree algorithms isÂ (Fang etÂ al., 2021), which adopts SS to train secure GBDT with data vertically partitioned to prevent intermediate information during training from leaking. Furthermore, it also provides an HE-based secure permutation method to accelerate the training process.

DP-Based Vertical Federated Tree Algorithm.

For theÂ S3 security model,Â (Weng etÂ al., 2020) designed the reverse sum attack where the malicious party encodes magic numbers in the ciphertext to steal the private data of other parties.Â (Luo etÂ al., 2021b) also designed attacks based on individual and multiple predictions. DP could be utilized to alleviate these attacks. For instance,Â (Le etÂ al., 2021) designed the FedXGBoost-LDP based on the noise perturbation of local DPÂ (Cormode etÂ al., 2018). Each party adds noises to every message before transmitting it. Therefore, the accumulated noises could severely affect model accuracy.Â (Wang etÂ al., 2022a) provided a solution with global DPÂ (Wei etÂ al., 2020a), where a selected leader adds noises. Furthermore, DP could also be leveraged to protect the prediction update leakage as a supplement to HEÂ (Zhu etÂ al., 2021a).

Vertical Federated Tree Algorithm with Other Protocols.

Besides FDMLÂ (Hu etÂ al., 2019), which could be used to build vertical federated tree models without HE, SS or, DP,Â (Wang etÂ al., 2022a) provided another method with an MPC-based secure aggregation protocol, which is similar toÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017). AndÂ (Le etÂ al., 2021) proposed the FedXGBoost-SMM algorithm based on the MPC-based secure matrix multiplication protocolÂ (Karr etÂ al., 2009).Â (Sheikhalishahi and Martinelli, 2017) proposed a privacy-preserving categorical clustering tree algorithm over vertically-partitioned data. More detailedly, this MPC-based work proposed the secure weighted averaging and secure comparison protocols to compute and compare the entropy of clusters at each leaf, thus deciding the splitting strategy.Â (Khodaparast etÂ al., 2018) also proposed a VFL method to train random decision trees via the same secure weighted average protocol. Besides,Â (Vaidya etÂ al., 2008) provides a novel vertical federated decision tree algorithm forÂ S2 adversaries.

Vertical Federated Neural Network Algorithm

Deep neural network (DNN)Â (Yegnanarayana, 2009) has become increasingly popular with the advances in high-quality, large-scale data and powerful computation facilities. DNNs generally contain stacked neural network layers and non-linear activation functions. Vertical federated neural network also takes a large portion in VFL. How to split the model under the concern of security and accuracy turns out to be the core design problem. We summarize these works in Tab.Â 4.

SplitNN-Based Vertical Federated Neural Network.

Existing vertical DNN models generally follow a split neural network (SplitNN) architectureÂ (Vepakomma etÂ al., 2018; Gupta and Raskar, 2018). In SplitNN, each passive party holds a local bottom model mapping features to latent embeddings, while the active party gathers the embeddings and combines them with its own features to complete the forward pass. Based on the SplitNN architecture, LiuÂ et al. proposed a specific VFL framework to solve visual-language-grounding problems such as image captioningÂ (Liu etÂ al., 2020b). Furthermore,Â (Cha etÂ al., 2021) utilizes an overcomplete autoencoder to generate embeddings in each party (task). Then, the latent representation from different parties is directly aggregated for a specific VFL task. The authors claim that the latent representation differs from the original data, thus, enabling security. In addition, LiÂ et al. utilized the SplitNN architecture to design a novel convolutional neural network (CNN)Â (Li etÂ al., 2021a) algorithm for image dataÂ (Li etÂ al., 2022a). Each party trains a local feature extractor and sends the latent representation to the server as the input of the classifier model. For graph data,Â (Zhang etÂ al., 2021d) defined the vertical federated graph neural network (GNN) algorithmÂ (Kipf and Welling, 2016; Hamilton etÂ al., 2017; Gilmer etÂ al., 2017) as all parties having the same set of nodes but different sets of edges and features.

Attack and Defence. The above works could achieve high-efficiency performance but contain severe privacy problems.Â (Fu etÂ al., 2022b) finds that SplitNN-based vertical federated neural network is vulnerable to label inference attack. Label inference attack is conducted by the passive party and aims to leak the labels owned by the active party. The authors proposed three kinds of label inference attack,Â i.e., passive label inference attack, active label inference attack, and direct label inference attack, for the SplitNN-based vertical neural network. Adversaries could infer the labels of the active party from both the received plaintext gradients and obtained plaintext final model weights. Although the proposed attacks are very effective, they make a strong assumption that auxiliary labels are provided for the adversary, which could be unavailable in practice. Besides,Â (Sun etÂ al., 2022b) indicated that the forward embedding could also disclose privacy.Â (Liu and Lyu, 2022) proposed a passive clustering inference attack to reveal the private labels.Â (Liu etÂ al., 2021c) designed the inversion and replacement attacks to disclose private labels from batch-level messages. In addition, since GNN is vulnerable to adversarial attacks,Â (Chen etÂ al., 2022b) designed a novel adversarial attack for vertical federated GNN model and found the attack is also effective. Besides,Â (Qiu etÂ al., 2022) designed novel attacks to reveal the leakage of samplesâ€™ relations.

The defense against these attacks is still an open problem, although many efforts have been made. For example, the authors ofÂ (Sun etÂ al., 2022b) proposed to alleviate leakage via reducing the correlation of the embedding and labels. Besides,Â (Cai etÂ al., 2022a) found out that there exists a trade-off between vulnerability to inference attacks and model accuracy. It designed a novel security forward aggregation (SFA) protocol to protect the privacy of raw data. In addition,Â (Li etÂ al., 2021b) indicated that randomly perturbing the gradients before transmission effectively protects privacy.Â (Sun etÂ al., 2021b) designed a framework (DRAVL) based on adversarial training, which could defend against reconstruction attacks. In addition,Â (Kholod etÂ al., 2021) studied the self-organizing map model for VFL. It proposes a parallelization method to reduce data transmission, thus decreasing the learning cost and privacy leakage risk. Besides, ZouÂ et al. found that batch-level intermediate results could also disclose the privacy of labelÂ (Zou etÂ al., 2022). The authors defended this attack with an adjustable autoencoder to confuse the adversary without hurting model accuracy. XiaÂ et al. proposed LabelGuard to defend against label inference attack via a novel learning methodÂ (Xia etÂ al., 2023). LabelGuard minimizes the VFL task training loss and the performance of estimated adversary models.Â (Liu etÂ al., 2021c) proposed a confusional autoencoder (CoAE) method to defend the label inference attack. Besides, YanÂ et al. utilized a practical secure aggregation protocol based on ECDHÂ (Barker etÂ al., 2017) to provide additional security guaranteeÂ (Yan etÂ al., 2022).

Training Data Insufficiency. Most VFL algorithms assume that labeled data is sufficient to train a high-quality model. However, it may not hold in VFL, as the training data are determined by the entity alignment of different parties. When only a limited number of entities co-exist among parties, we will face the problem of training data and label scarcity. Several methods aim to transfer knowledge among similar samples to complement missing features. For the scenarios where parties own sample IDs to conduct PSI, KangÂ et al. proposed FedCVT as a multi-view learning framework to utilize non-overlapping entities for VFL via pseudo-feature and pseudo-label generationÂ (Kang etÂ al., 2022). Consider the two-party case, the overlapping samples form a cross-party view, while non-overlapping samples at each party form unique intra-party views. For each party, two neural networks are learned to capture features for the cross-party and intra-party views. Pseudo-features and labels are generated by querying the intra-party view of the other party via dot-product attention. Besides,Â (Zhang etÂ al., 2022d) also utilizes GANÂ (Goodfellow etÂ al., 2020) to address the shortage problem of overlapping entities. The authors generate more training samples by learning from the feature correlation of limited aligned entities and abundant unaligned ones.Â (Chu and Zhang, 2021) performs self-taught learningÂ (Raina etÂ al., 2007) over all local samples at each party to extract useful features and benefit the VFL training process.Â (Wang etÂ al., 2022b) applies knowledge distillationÂ (Hinton etÂ al., 2015; Gou etÂ al., 2021) on the federated representation of shared samples learned byÂ (Chai etÂ al., 2021) and transfers the knowledge to enrich the representation of local samples.Â (Ren etÂ al., [n.â€‰d.]) also provides a solution based on knowledge distillation. The well-trained VFL model is regarded as a teacher model to generate teacher labels for the aligned entities. Then, a local student model is trained with both local labels and teacher labels to realize knowledge transfer. Moreover,Â (Feng, 2022) proposed to utilize the non-overlapping samples to conduct vertical federated feature selection. Furthermore, when using PPRL instead of PSI for entity alignment in the scenarios like GPS location, the output of entity alignment is the similarity score but not binary matching result,Â i.e., aligned or unaligned. For using such similarity results, we could turn them to binary results with a threshold. However, this intuitive method causes information loss. To address this problem, WuÂ et al. consider an alternative case where parties have overlapping features, upon which top-kğ‘˜k fuzzy sample matching can be performedÂ (Wu etÂ al., 2021). Specifically, for each sample iğ‘–i in party A, a secure top-kğ‘˜k nearest neighbor search is performed in party B. The top-kğ‘˜k similar samples of iğ‘–i will be fed into the VFL model via a weighted sum to complement its features.

HE-Based Vertical Federated Neural Network.

Based on the architecture of SplitNN,Â (Zhang and Zhu, 2020) combined Paillier with multiplicative RM to protect the privacy of the aggregated embedding. To reduce the communication cost introduced by Paillier, FLFHNNÂ (Sun etÂ al., 2022c) adopted the CKKS scheme as the privacy-preserving method. Besides, CheungÂ et al. proposed an HE-based vertical federated GNNÂ (Cheung etÂ al., 2021), designed without activation functions, thus being linear and well supported by HE. Furthermore, NiÂ et al. also studied vertical GNN via HE, tackling the non-linear activation functions via approximationÂ (Ni etÂ al., 2021). Moreover,Â (Li etÂ al., 2022b) proposed an HE-based sample strategy of imbalanced data for vertical federated graph embedding.

SS-Based Vertical Federated Neural Network.

We could also adopt SS instead of SplitNN from the two-party settingÂ (Demmler etÂ al., 2015; Mohassel and Zhang, 2017; Huang etÂ al., 2022b), three-party settingÂ (Mohassel and Rindal, 2018) to four-party settingÂ (Dalskov etÂ al., 2021). The SS-based approaches allow more strict security models,Â e.g.,Â S3, but always suffer from worse efficiency. Besides,Â (Zhou etÂ al., 2020) takes a different approach to implement vertical GNN by distributing and gathering node embeddings from different parties using SS. DP is also adopted to enhance privacy. In addition, BlindFL combined HE and SS to design a vertical federated learning method, which is suitable for sparse and categorical featuresÂ (Fu etÂ al., 2022a). We could regard BlindFL as an extension of CAESARÂ (Chen etÂ al., 2021a). YangÂ et al. also proposed a hybrid protocol for VFLÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2023), where SS and GC support linear and non-linear operations separately.

DP-Based Vertical Federated Neural Network.

Vertical federated NN algorithms based on NN have also been studied. For example, TPSL adopted the DP technique to make obfuscation to defend against the label leakage attackÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2022). It permutes both the model weights and the transmitted intermediate results to provide a provable guarantee.Â (Liang etÂ al., 2021) proposed a self-supervised solution to neural architecture search (NAS)Â (Zhu etÂ al., 2021b) for VFL with differential privacy. In addition, PengÂ et al. proposed a DP-based method to further improve the embeddings of non-overlapping entities in the vertical federated knowledge graphs embedding taskÂ (Peng etÂ al., 2021). Besides,Â (Chen etÂ al., 2020a) combined DP with the asynchronous LSTM-based method and analyzed its convergence. With the adoption of DP, FedOnceÂ (Wu etÂ al., 2022a) showed that privacy loss is accumulated across not only iterations but also parties. Therefore, FedOnce proposed a new DP mechanism to slow down inter-party privacy loss.

Other Vertical Federated Algorithms

Besides vertical federated linear, tree, and neural network algorithms, other VFL algorithms exist, which are essential for real-world scenarios. We conclude them in Tab.Â 5.

Other Vertical Federated Algorithms Based on HE.

OuÂ et al. studied Expectation maximization (EM) algorithms in the VFL scenarioÂ (Ou etÂ al., 2020). EM algorithms are commonly used to infer probabilistic generative models with latent variables, such as k-means, topic models, variational autoencoders,Â etc. The authors proposed an HE-based algorithm that performs E steps locally and M steps using aggregated parameters. HE-based protocol is used to encrypt local calculation results. VaidyaÂ et al. proposed a privacy-preserving K-means clustering model on vertically partitioned dataÂ (Vaidya and Clifton, 2003). The algorithm is developed based on a secure add-and-compare protocol and an HE-based secure permutation protocol to secretly assign each sample to the nearest cluster. The authors also discussed situations where the adversaries areÂ S2 andÂ S3.

Other Vertical Federated Algorithms Based on SS.

(Chen etÂ al., 2020b) proposed SeSoRec as a vertical federated recommendation framework based on matrix factorization with MPC-based protocol. SeSoRec could allow collaborative training between the user-item interaction and user social platforms. Besides,Â (Zhang etÂ al., 2022e) utilized SS to design a feature selection method based on Gini impurity, which could improve the accuracy of down-stream learning task. Furthermore, the authors enhanced the protocol with the additional HE adoption to reduce communication overhead.

Other Vertical Federated Algorithms Based on Other Protocols.

(Yu etÂ al., 2006) studied kernel methods in support vector machines (SVM) over vertically partitioned data. The kernel method is a broad class of non-linear machine learning modelsÂ (Hofmann etÂ al., 2008) commonly used in bioinformatics. The critical insight ofÂ (Yu etÂ al., 2006) is to represent the kernel function as matrices computed locally and to recover the global kernel matrix via secure sum protocols. However,Â (Yu etÂ al., 2006) suffers from communication overhead caused by merging local kernel matrices. Therefore,Â (Yunhong etÂ al., 2009) designed a more efficient protection method for SVM with matrix factorization theory. Besides, CheungÂ et al. studied the problem of principle component analysis in VFLÂ (Cheung etÂ al., 2022). The authors leverage power iteration locally to compute eigenvalues and eigenvectors of local covariance matrices before merging the local eigenvectors to form the global eigenvector. Moreover, the authors propose a fully decentralized version to perform PCA in VFL, with eigenvectors communication between immediate neighbors. They stated that this work fulfills the standard security,Â i.e., only intermediate results are transmitted while raw data is maintained locally.Â (Vaidya and Clifton, 2002) provided a vertical federated association rule mining algorithm, which designed an RM-based secure scalar product method. This method only allows computation over private data but discloses no privacy. In addition,Â (Dang etÂ al., 2020) proposed to leverage a random feature approximation technique to decouple non-linear kernels into linearly separable computations. In addition, AtarashiÂ et al. proposed to learn high-order factorization machinesÂ (Blondel etÂ al., 2016), a commonly used model in recommender system, under the VFL settingÂ (Atarashi and Ishihata, 2021). They use ANOVA kernelsâ€™ recursion and can be applied with HE to enhance privacy.Â (Gu etÂ al., 2020) proposed a vertical federated kernel algorithm,Â i.e., FDSKL, which could handle linearly non-separable data. This RM-based method considers both data privacy and model privacy. FDSKL extended the synchronous gradient descent algorithmÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2019b) to non-linear kernel methods.

(D4) Compiler of vertical federated machine learning algorithm. Currently, various vertical federated machine learning algorithms need different hand-crafted designs, while HFL has an unified architecture. This is why SOTA machine learning algorithms,Â e.g., large language modelsÂ (Brown etÂ al., 2020), are always hard to be adopted in VFL. Therefore, the VFL compiler is of urgent need to automatically design federated algorithms given arbitary machine learning models and privacy-preserving primitives.

(D5) Hybrid privacy-preserving protocol. We observe that different security primitives have their own pros and cons. For example, SS-based protocols own large communication overheads but scarcely affect accuracy, while DP-based protocols could maintain good efficiency but suffer from severe accuracy loss. In the future, there will be more hybrid protocols to balance different costs.

6. Layer Four: System Design of VFL

Based on different vertical federated algorithms, the VFL system is designed in various aspects, such as incentive mechanism, interpretability, efficiency optimization, robustness enhancement, and verification.

6.1. Incentive Mechanism

The incentive mechanism plays an essential role in designing the VFL framework for commercial usage, which could promote the truth-telling of the participants and fair profit allocation, consequently encouraging more parties to join the VFL community. In this section, we introduce a common monetary incentive mechanism design where participants purchase in a monetary way. The design contains two types of roles,Â i.e., model user and data provider, shown in Fig.Â 5. Data providers contribute data with cost,Â e.g., data collection and preprocessing. Model users utilize the provided dataset in a privacy-preserving manner to build a machine learning model, which brings value,Â e.g., model performance improvement. Consequently, the model users must transfer a certain amount of payoff to the data providers. Specifically, each model user holds a certain budget amount, which will be subsequently distributed to the data providers as the payoff. The VFL monetary incentive mechanism design mainly contains three aspects: 1) the contribution evaluation of each data provider; 2) the quantification of supply-side data cost and demand-side model value; 3) the design of payoff sharing schema,Â i.e., determining the demand-side budget and supply-side payoff.

6.1.1. Contribution Evaluation.

Datasets from different providers should have non-identical contributions to the demand sideâ€™s model. Intuitively, providers with high contributions deserve a better payoff. An accurate evaluation of individual providersâ€™ contributions can promote fairness in FL. Recent work has been proposed to use the Shapley value in evaluating dataâ€™s contributionÂ (Liu etÂ al., 2020a; Wei etÂ al., 2020b; Wang etÂ al., 2020b, 2019). However, Shapley value has an exponential time complexity, thus very inefficient.Â (Wang etÂ al., 2022c) proposed to directly discard part of the computation of Shapley value, which could cause an error within 5%. Besides, other approximation methods,Â e.g., Monte-Carlo sampling, are designed to improve the computation efficiencyÂ (Wei etÂ al., 2020b; Wang etÂ al., 2019, 2020b). In real-world applications, the federation or model users could run a sandbox simulation to calculate each data providerâ€™s contribution. Besides, the contribution evaluation methods are supposed to be robust against the cheating behaviors from the data providers. For example, if the data providers know the contribution evaluating rules,Â e.g., the corresponding test dataset, they could generate data with high contribution value using low cost, and the data is useless for the modeling task.

6.1.2. Evaluation of Cost and Value.

The accurate assessments of the supply-side data cost and the demand-size model value are essential for the incentive mechanism design. There could be many ways for calculation. A straightforward method is building a computational model based on market research, which might be complicated because it is hard to design one computational model that fits all VFL scenarios. Apart from the computational model design, another solution is the self-report when the cost and value information are privately known. An auction-based self-report could be used in evaluating the supply-side data cost. Specifically, the federation can ask each data owner to request payment for the data contribution and then select which data owner shall join the federation. An example of the auction-based self-report on the data owner side is using the PVCG modelÂ (Cong etÂ al., 2020). The truth-telling self-report of demand-side model value needs the accomplishment of incentive compatibility, such that the model users could get the best outcome if they report the true model value. To achieve incentive compatibility, the authors proposed to find the Nash equilibrium, which is similar toÂ (Lu etÂ al., 2022). Besides,Â (Zhang etÂ al., 2022d) proposed to abstract the data transaction process of VFL to a Stackelberg price competition model. Then, we could conduct a reverse analysis to obtain the optimal data pricing strategy.

6.1.3. Payoff Sharing Schema Design.

The payoff sharing schema design determines how much the model users should pay to the data providers. The pay-off sharing schema is non-trivial and challenging because it has many objectives: 1)Â Incentive compatibility. A VFL incentive mechanism should ensure that participants can achieve the best or at least not the worst outcome by reporting the truth regarding the cost and value; 2)Â Individual rationality. The mechanism should not make any party worse off than if he quits the federation. In other words, each data providerâ€™s payoff is greater than the cost, and each model userâ€™s model value is greater than the budget; 3)Â Budget balance. Model usersâ€™ budget could cover the payoff of data providers. A mechanism is called strong budget balanced if budget equals payoff; 4)Â Social surplus optimization. Social surplus is the sum of consumer surplus and producer surplus,Â i.e., data cost and model value. A mechanism is called social surplus optimized when the social surplus is maximized; 5)Â Fairness. The received payoff should be fair among the data providers. Specifically, data with higher contribution to the model or higher cost should be rewarded more payoff. Besides, the fairness of mechanism should also be robust to cheating from the data provider side; 6)Â Punishing the attacks. A mechanism should be able to punish malicious parties if any attack is detected; 7)Â Eliminating payment delay. A mechanism should try to eliminate payment delay incurred by model training time to prevent budget deficit. For example, data owner Aâ€™s data is contributed with high cost but has few improvements for model user Bâ€™s task. If B pays A until the whole training process is finished, B will likely meet the budget deficit.

Besides, there exist trade-offs among the above objectives. Thus, building one incentive mechanism to optimize all objectives is unrealistic. For example, more optimizing targets usually result in worse social optimizationÂ (Cong etÂ al., 2020). In practice, we could select a subset of targets according to scenarios. CongÂ et al. proposed a demand-side Cremer-McLean mechanism to optimize the incentive compatibility and individual rationality togetherÂ (Cong etÂ al., 2020).

(D6) Fair incentive mechanism. As a technique highly related to business, VFL needs a fair incentive mechanism to ensure equitable payment for each party contributing to the training process, encouraging more new users to join the community. However, the incentive mechanism in VFL is still an open problem.

6.2. Interpretability

VFL is commonly applied in areas (e.g., financial scenarios) that severely need interpretability. Interpretability could improve data quality and help to understand the decision-making process. Therefore, enhancing the interpretability of VFL is also an essential problem. For example, KangÂ et al. proposed an explainable VFL approach to help the domain adaptation processÂ (Kang etÂ al., 2021). The features of an auxiliary party to guide the adaptation are split into groups using expertise knowledge in advance. They assign a separate feature extractor for each feature group to obtain interpretable transferable features.Â (Chen etÂ al., 2022a) designed an explainable VFL framework based on counterfactual explanationÂ (Mothilal etÂ al., 2020) to evaluate feature importance for VFL.

However, there exist conflicts between interpretability and privacy in VFL. For instance, anonymous features are often utilized in VFL to avoid privacy leakage, which harms the explainability of model. To address this problem,Â (Chen etÂ al., 2021b) proposed an interpretable inference framework for vertical tree ensemble models. It discloses the feature meanings to other parties but encrypts the decision path for security.

6.3. Efficiency Optimization

Based on the architecture proposed by YangÂ et al.Â (Yang etÂ al., 2019b), we introduce several innovative works that improve efficiency and effectiveness. They could be summarized as pipeline and compression.

6.3.1. Pipeline.

Current VFL design suffers from â€œLiebigâ€™s Lawâ€Â 444https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liebig%27s_law_of_the_minimum, that the overall efficiency is limited by slow participants. Besides the asynchronized designs inÂ Â§5.2.2, there exist other pipeline methods to alleviate the efficiency problem. For example, VF2Boost addressed the mutual-waiting problem in VFL via an optimistic node-splitting methodÂ (Fu etÂ al., 2021). The active party directly splits tree nodes according to his own data without waiting for information from the passive party. A roll-back operation is designed for correcting wrong splits.

6.3.2. Compression.

Another method to improve communication efficiency in VFL is compression. For example, LiÂ et al. proposed a double-end sparse compression method to reduce the additional intermediate results transmissionÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020). On both the active and passive parties, only the results with large changes will be transmitted. Moreover, the changes in the results which are not transmitted will be accumulated locally until large enough. Similarly, YangÂ et al. adopted the same compression method, which only transmits important updates larger than a given threshold and accumulates the remaining updates locallyÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2021). Besides,Â (Khan etÂ al., 2022) adopted PCA and autoencoder to reduce the dimension of transmitted message. From another point of view, according to the properties of HE, VF2Boost designed a polynomial-based packing method to conduct compression. They find that the encoded integer of each value locates in a narrow range, therefore packing multiple ciphers into a single one to reduce the total transmission amount of intermediate resultsÂ (Fu etÂ al., 2021).

6.4. Robustness Enhancement

Robustness is another important problem for VFL. We introduce the robustness enhancement approaches in VFL considering three aspects,Â i.e., multiple party scenario, dynamic party handling, and multi-tiered network structure.

6.4.1. Multiple Party Scenario.

Current researchers mainly consider the two-party VFL setting because it is more common in practiceÂ (Chen etÂ al., 2021a). However, with the development of privacy-preserving techniquesÂ (Chauhan etÂ al., 2020), the multiple party scenario of VFL is becoming an important topic. Among the existing works,Â (Sun etÂ al., 2022a; Shi etÂ al., 2022) proposed to utilize the secure aggregation methodÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) for intermediate results communication, which could easily suit the multiple party setting. The HE and SS hybrid protocol proposed byÂ (Huang etÂ al., 2022a) also supports flexible expansion to multiple parties.Â (Feng and Yu, 2020) adopts a multi-participant framework based on multi-view learningÂ (Xu etÂ al., 2013). Furthermore,Â (Mugunthan etÂ al., 2021) introduces a scenario where labels also distribute among multiple parties.Â (Li etÂ al., 2022c) proposed a ring architecture for multi-party communication to avoid the complexity of protocol and reduce the effect third party. Besides,Â (Zeng etÂ al., 2022) proposed a fast global aggregation method based on the over-the-air computation (AirComp) technologyÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2020b) for scenarios with a large number of participants. AirComp could utilize the superposition property of wireless multiple access channels to concurrently transmit local intermediate results.

6.4.2. Dynamic Party Handling.

The dynamic party is much more common in HFL than in VFL. However, the handling of dynamic parties is also essential when the number of participants in VFL increases. For example,Â (Zhang etÂ al., 2022f) provided a scheduling policy based on the truncation threshold to silence the parties with a low transmission rate, which could reduce communication latency while maintaining convergence. Several works have already invesgated on this topic. ZhouÂ et al. proposed to utilize SS to solve the participant dropout problemÂ (Zhou etÂ al., 2021). The aggregated messages will only be decrypted if they come from enough participants. Besides, HouÂ et al. designed additional handling for both dynamic parties join and dropout problemsÂ (Hou etÂ al., 2021). The secure aggregation methodÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) adopted byÂ (Sun etÂ al., 2022a; Shi etÂ al., 2022) could also solve the dropout problems by utilizing SS.

6.4.3. Hierarchical Network Structure.

Most existing VFL works only consider a one-tiered network, where the participants maintain data locally. However, in reality, the network structure of VFL could be hierarchical. The participants of VFL also consist of a group of data silos. For instance, two companies want to conduct VFL, and the data of each company is maintained distributedly in sub-companies. DasÂ et al. designed a novel VFL algorithm for a two-tiered scenario where each party (i.e., hub) in VFL contains a group of clients with horizontally-partitioned dataÂ (Das and Patterson, 2021). For one iteration, firstly, each hub aggregates model parameters and intermediate results with the corresponding clients. Then, all hubs communicate intermediate results with each other for computing model updates. Finally, the hub broadcast updates to its clients. Besides,Â (Kang etÂ al., 2021) also introduces a novel hierarchical structure where two parties first extend their feature space from an auxiliary party via VFL, and then those two parties could conduct domain adaptation. ValdeiraÂ et al. applied the parallel Markov chain coordinate descent algorithm in a semi-decentralized setting, combining both client-client and client-server communication, to improve efficiencyÂ (Valdeira etÂ al., [n.â€‰d.]). TDCDÂ (Das etÂ al., 2022) and VHFLÂ (Wan etÂ al., 2022) are proposed for the two-tiered network scenario, where the data is horizontally and vertically partitioned sequentially.

6.5. Verification

In real-world scenarios, participants are malicious with a high probability, which conflicts with the semi-honest assumption of most VFL papers. A simple and effective method is to arm the system with verification and audit functions. There are some pilot works on this topic. For instance, HouÂ et al. adopted a verifiable computation method proposed byÂ (Backes etÂ al., 2013) to check the data integrityÂ (Hou etÂ al., 2021). This method could verify if the results generated by messages that parties transmit to the server have been modified. Besides, ZhangÂ et al. designed a verification framework whose clients are deployed separately at all participants to monitor the transferred messagesÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2021e). They define VFL tasks as finite state machines uniformly, therefore the framework could adapt to different VFL algorithms. Furthermore, blockchainÂ (Zheng etÂ al., 2018) could also be used to ensure a trustworthy federated training processÂ (urÂ Rehman etÂ al., 2020; Dias and Meratnia, 2023; Cheng etÂ al., 2022).

(D7) Reliable verification. The malicious adversary in the real world is one of the largest obstacles to adopt VFL. Verification is the easiest and most effective method for defending malicious adversaries. However, there is no uniform solution to verification.

7. Layer Five: Application Design of VFL

VFL is typically an application-driven technique recently adopted in finance, healthcare, recommender system,Â etc. The portion of each application area is shown in Fig.Â 6, based on the papers we have investigated. In this section, we introduce these applications in detail, including the background, problem, and solution.

7.1. Finance

Finance is an important application area of VFLÂ (Gupta and Raskar, 2018; Ou etÂ al., 2020; Yang etÂ al., 2019b; Cheng etÂ al., 2021a; Li etÂ al., 2022b; Hardy etÂ al., 2017). In finance, many scenarios,Â e.g., risk managementÂ (Leo etÂ al., 2019) and marketingÂ (Ma and Sun, 2020), are driven by big data and machine learning algorithms. In detail, risk managementÂ (Leo etÂ al., 2019) is to make judgments on whether one user can be trusted to issue a loan or credit card. The risk becomes high if the loan is given to people who cannot pay it back. Financial marketingÂ (Ma and Sun, 2020) is the process of selecting candidate customers from a large group of people such that the selected candidates are more likely to purchase the related financial products. Machine learning models,Â e.g., linear regressionÂ (Maulud and Abdulazeez, 2020), gradient boosting treeÂ (Ke etÂ al., 2017), and neural networkÂ (Yegnanarayana, 2009), are commonly used in these scenarios. Financial institutions usually lack enough user portraits for model training. Therefore, VFL could provide a secure way to utilize rich data features from other companies,Â e.g., Internet company.

Among these applications,Â (Yang etÂ al., 2019b) andÂ (Hardy etÂ al., 2017) proposed vertical federated linear and logistic regression, respectively.Â (Cheng etÂ al., 2021a) proposed vertical federated boosting tree model. They adopt HE to protect the transmitted intermediate results and achieve privacy preservation. More works about vertical linear, tree, and neural network models,Â e.g.,Â (Cha etÂ al., 2021), are investigated in SectionÂ 5. Besides,Â (Gupta and Raskar, 2018) proposed a split-learning framework for financial applications when financial institutions are short of labeled data and computational resources.Â (Li etÂ al., 2022b) proposed to utilize vertical federated GNN in the financial area.Â (Ou etÂ al., 2020) proposed a HE-based vertical federated Bayesian learning model for risk management.

7.2. Healthcare

Many researchers investigated the application of VFL in the healthcare area, such asÂ (Pfitzner etÂ al., 2021; Gupta and Raskar, 2018; Li etÂ al., 2016; Kim etÂ al., 2021; Lee etÂ al., 2018; Errounda and Liu, 2022; Zhang etÂ al., 2022e),Â etc. Vertically partitioned data is quite common in healthcareÂ (Pfitzner etÂ al., 2021). Due to the unique characteristic of medical information, the leakage of medical data may bring severe issues like social discrimination. Therefore, VFL can be helpful to enrich the data features of patients. For example, multiple medical institutions,Â e.g., hospitals, own different records for the same patients. They could securely train better models for healthcare tasks with VFL.

Among these applications,Â (Li etÂ al., 2016) provided a new binary LR method to predict the mortality for breast cancer and myocardial infarction, using genome, electronic health records, and intensive care unit data.Â (Kim etÂ al., 2021) further improved this method and verified its performance on a task that analyzes the association between coronary artery disease and cardiovascular risk factors. Besides,Â (Gupta and Raskar, 2018) proposed a split-learning framework for healthcare applications.Â (Lee etÂ al., 2018) designed a VFL patient similarity learning algorithm, which could be used to construct datasets for cross-silo observational studies, disease surveillance, and clinical trial recruitment. The experiments show that the proposed algorithm is effective in the prediction tasks of five diseases,Â i.e., disorders of lipoid metabolism, hypertensive chronic kidney disease, cardiac dysrhythmias, heart failure, and acute renal failure. Besides, MVFFÂ (Errounda and Liu, 2022) is proposed as a mobility forecasting VFL method, which could be used to predict the spread of COVID-19Â (Ilin etÂ al., 2021).Â (Zhang etÂ al., 2022e) designed the VFL feature selection algorithm to improve deep learning modelsâ€™ accuracy in electronic health (eHealth) systemsÂ (Evans, 2016).

7.3. Recommender System

The recommender system (RecSys) is another popular application scenario of VFLÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2020b; Atarashi and Ishihata, 2021; Tan etÂ al., 2020; Song etÂ al., 2021; Chen etÂ al., 2020b). RecSys is widely adopted in peopleâ€™s daily life. For example, we can see our favorite items and articles when we shop and read news online via RecSys. The core of RecSys is to predict whether a user is interested in one specific item based on the side information of users and items as well as usersâ€™ historical behaviorsÂ (Lu etÂ al., 2015). The prediction will have better performance if more training data is provided. Hence, VFL could be a feasible solution considering the privacy concerns and data silo problem.

The vertical federated recommender (FedRec) system refers to the scenarios where multiple parties hold the historical behaviors or side information for the same group of usersÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2020b). For instance, an online library service provider with usersâ€™ reading history can cooperate with the online movie watching company, which contains watching history to enrich the data features and obtain better recommendation accuracy.Â (Tan etÂ al., 2020) proposed an open-source FedRec system, providing the vertical federared implementation of many recommendation algorithms,Â e.g., matrix factorizationÂ (Koren etÂ al., 2009), factorization machineÂ (Rendle, 2010), and wide & deep learningÂ (Cheng etÂ al., 2016). The system has been deployed for a real-world recommendation application and achieves performance improvement. Besides,Â (Atarashi and Ishihata, 2021) proposed a vertical higher-order factorization machine to capture high-order feature interactions among data silos.Â (Song etÂ al., 2021) provided a SecureBoost-based system to improve recommendation accuracy with data in mobile network operators and healthcare providers.Â (Chen etÂ al., 2020b) designed an MPC-based vertical federated social recommendation framework.

7.4. Computer Vision and Natural Language Processing

Apart from the recommender system in the Internet area, VFL is also explored in the computer visionÂ (Forsyth and Ponce, 2011) and natural language processingÂ (Chowdhary, 2020) area. For instance,Â (Liu etÂ al., 2020b) proposed a federated learning framework to fuse various types of image representations from different tasks to form fine-grained image representations. Both visual and textual features are contained in these tasks. By generating fine-grained representations, their framework improves performance on various vision and language grounding problems without sharing downstream task data.Â (Li etÂ al., 2022a) proposed a vertical federated CNN algorithm for the image classification task, where parties hold incomplete pieces for the same group of images. The accuracy of designed VFL method is close to the one of centralized method.

7.5. Manufacturing

The applications of VFL in the field of manufacturing containÂ (Aggour etÂ al., 2019; Ge etÂ al., 2021; Wu etÂ al., 2022b; Mao etÂ al., 2023; Xia etÂ al., 2022). The manufacturing process usually crosses different companies, workshops, or even production lines (Ge etÂ al., 2021). Due to the privacy-preserving regulations, manufacturing data could not be collected together to train models, which becomes the bottleneck of intelligent manufacturing. NingÂ et al. proposed the vertical federated SVD and random forest algorithm for failure prediction in the production lineÂ (Ge etÂ al., 2021). The proposed models are validated on public datasets in intelligent manufacturing. XiaÂ et al. further applied a vertical federated XGBoost algorithm in the task of failure predictionÂ (Xia etÂ al., 2022). In addition,Â (Aggour etÂ al., 2019) designed a federated multimodal learning platform for additive manufacturingÂ (Frazier, 2014). WuÂ et al. proposed a federated frequent itemsets mining framework for industrial collaborative activities of the supply chain networkÂ (Wu etÂ al., 2022b). Besides,Â (Mao etÂ al., 2023) applied vertical federated XGBoost in the power grid area to power load forecasting, which is vital for the stability of power systems and reduction of cost.

7.6. Telecommunication

VFL has also been applied in the telecommunication areaÂ (Subramanya and Riggio, 2021; Zhang etÂ al., 2020b; Hashemi etÂ al., 2021; Sacco etÂ al., 2020; Zhang etÂ al., 2022f; Zeng etÂ al., 2022; Liu etÂ al., 2022). In telecommunication, conventional centralized learning requires data from multiple data sources, which could leak the private data of each party. Thus, VFL is adopted to support telecommunication in different aspects. For example, TejasÂ et al. proposed a vertical autoscaling algorithm for intelligent end-to-end management and orchestration of network resources in the multi-domain 5G networksÂ (Subramanya and Riggio, 2021).Â (Zeng etÂ al., 2022) provided a communication-computation co-design for the 6G networkÂ (Letaief etÂ al., 2021).Â (Zhang etÂ al., 2020b) designed a VFL-based cooperative sensing scheme for cognitive radio networks. Besides,Â (Hashemi etÂ al., 2021) proposed a VFL algorithm for collaborative model training in disaggregated networks. The algorithm is used to classify the quality of transmission. In addition,Â (Sacco etÂ al., 2020) proposed a VFL architecture for routing packets in the challenged network with varying conditions and high-volumne traffic.Â (Zhang etÂ al., 2022f) designed a low-latency VFL algorithm to improve the accuracy of spectrum sensingÂ (Hussain and Fernando, 2009), which is used in the area of wireless communication. Besides,Â (Liu etÂ al., 2022) applied VFL in the task of motion recognition to exploit the multi-view observation data from different wireless sensing devices.

8. Conclusion

In this paper, we show the current development situation of vertical federated learning. From a layered perspective, we discuss the current works and explore the challenges of designing a vertical federated learning framework for all layers. Although the flourishing growth momentum has appeared in different application areas recently, the research of vertical federated learning is still in its infancy. As a technique full of commercial values, vertical federated learning is a topic that deserves to be studied.
